job_title: Cloud Support Associate in Cape Town
pros:
Some beneficial technical experience to be gained.
Company name looks good on your CV.
Intelligent colleagues to learn from.
cons:
Worst job I've had. Managers pretend to be empathetic, but really they only care about the "metrics" (how many calls, chats, email cases you are taking and resolving). Despite what is said, this is really a call centre roll and you are treated as an expendable commodity.

Even if you meet the goal and are performing well, you can suddenly find yourself on a "coaching plan", as managers actually have a goal themselves as to how many people should be on performance management plan at any one time. Competition between employees is also encouraged/highlighted, which leads to a tense and stressful work environment. This is probably what Amazon believes is good motivation though!

You are told that weekend shifts will be temporary and that you will rotate, but this was not the case for me and I was stuck working weekends for 3 years, despite constant requests to change.

HR are only interested in protecting the company image, so any employee concerns are likely to get brushed aside and hushed up, as quickly as possible.

My advice is to stay away.

job_title: Program Manager II in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I'm giving Amazon five stars because, truly, the culture is incredible. Everyone during my onboarding has been incredibly helpful. No one says "That's not my job" but actually takes time to help you and give you the insider scoop. It's scary as hell because I'm allowed to innovate for a HUGE audience. Huge meaning over 100k people that I impact. How much scarier can a job get? But, at the same time, can it get more exciting and interesting than this?? I submit that it cannot.
cons: Onboarding is good, but it's not really job-specific. It would have been more helpful to have an onboarding buddy in my timezone, and someone to shadow me during my first program launches to at least give some sort of guiderail on how PMing is done here at Amazon. Plus, it would have helped a lot to have an onboarding buddy that helps me in navigating the political nuances of the leadership team. Also, I'm still 0% sure what my measures of success are. That makes me nervous.

review_title: A lot of pros with serious cons!
pros:
These are for Amazon Luxembourg
- Work hours are flexible
- WFH is available
- Free fruits!
- Great relocation benefit! 
- EU Blue card sponsorship which allow you to stay and work 4 years
- Additional health insurance (on top of mandatory one)
- Reimbursement for kids school
- Lunch tickets
- Great espresso machines!
cons:
These are for Amazon Luxembourg
- Very low salary compared to Amazon in the US (almost 40% is deducted due to taxes and health insurance). It is not possible to live by on a single salary if you have a family which brings me to the second point.
- It is very hard for spouses to find a job in Luxembourg unless they know French/German/Luxembourgish and obtaining work permit for them is very painful
- Small offices

job_title: Seasonal Sortation Associate in Hawthorne, CA
pros: -part-time hours - location - decent pay
cons: - upper management - point system

pros:
1. On the job training, with a small handful of excellent trainers.
Easy to get the job as a temp/seasonal worker and then to move to permanent employee status.
2. Opportunities for advancement.
3. Consistent shift start time. Never had a shift cancelled.
4. Many opportunities for extra shifts, especially around the holidays and busy national business events.
cons:
1. "Too many cooks." Widespread internal inconsistencies made doing the simple, moderately physically intensive work unnecessarily confusing/difficult because individual members of management were constantly contradicting or overriding other members of management or otherwise playing office politics. Our training department was especially prone to corruption.

2. Lack of accountability for both associates and management, often leading to recurring safety issues that were not effectively addressed.

3. Lack of follow-through from management. Regular promises/agreements were made and then discarded casually or became issues when other members of management became involved, which was often. Some members would then gas-light you, and there was little recourse for targets of this degeneracy.

job_title: FC Associate I in Bessemer, AL
pros:
*Set shift: You always know what days and what times you work. This only changes during busy times of year (Peak season). Full-time employees work 4-5/7 days, Reduced time employees work 3-4 days/7, Part-time employees work 2 days/7
*Benefits: Full-time associates get access to health, dental, and vision insurance on day one.
*Tuition assistance: $5200 up front for nearly any, not just those that relate to Amazon, AS or BS program from a select list of schools for full time Associates. It's around $2000 for part-time
cons:
*Pay: Low in comparison to other warehouse jobs
*Isolation: There's a feeling of isolation. Part of this is due to being stuck at my station all day long. Part of it is the fact that there must be a lot of opportunity for career advancement for the managers. I have worked here 2 years and have had a least 5 or 6 managers, so you don't really have the chance to get to know your manager.
*Schedule: The schedule is a pro and a con 4 work days and 3 off days is nice, but I hate the job so much that I'm too exhausted to enjoy the 3 off days. I'm not sure if an 8-hour/5 day shift is a better solution here, but I'd be willing to try.
*Repetitiveness: 10 hours/day at one station doing the same task over and over all day long in a dimly lit, windowless warehouse with almost no human contact slowly drives you insane.

review_title: Good place to learn, not so great to climb the career ladder
pros:
- There are plenty of opportunities to learn
- If you don't like your team, with some tact you can switch easily to another team 
- Work is meaningful
- Great benefits
- Opportunities to work remote or hybrid
cons:
- As a security engineer, average salary is below value you deliver to the company. 
- Promotion process is a bit ridiculous. Ones who are good at bragging and spicing up should expect to get promoted faster. Ones who are humble or not great at their writing skills have hard time getting promoted. Most engineers tend to leave the company having spent 4-6 years at the company as they prefer to get promoted by leaving the company rather than going through the internal process.
- Promotion bar are not consistent across the company. In some teams, managers do realize the ridiculousness described above and promote fairly where as others don't. 
- Work life balance is not consistent across teams. Some teams do much better than others. Realize that negative experiences are usually more talked about.

review_title: Not many benefits but competitive pay
pros:
- Company tries to keep good work/life balance
- Top pay employer
- 1st year and 2nd year bonus, 100% guaranteed
- Stocks vesting in 4 years
- Relocation and immigration assistance
- Bright and talented people in the company
- Focus in automation rather than repetitive tasks
- Flexible WFH
cons:
- Few or none perks and benefits
- Not the best dental and health insurance out there, many things are not covered
- Frugality. Apart from a good salary, don't expect free snacks at work or group events as they are considered unnecessary.
- Your team can be split in different timezones, making it difficult to collaborate
- Micromanagement in daily stand ups
- Like any other big company, it's difficult to get things done
- Everyone is going after a promotion, meaning they don't have time to help in other projects unless it benefits them
- In general, people leave after their 4th anniversary since there are no more bonuses or stocks
- Some teams do 24 hr week oncall, once every 6 weeks
- At least in Dublin, the housing crisis makes things 1000 times more difficult, 40%-50% of your salary will be wasted on rent

job_title: Tier III Process Assistant in Markham, IL
pros: You get a consistent set schedule, and the company keeps expanding including pay raises.
cons:
If you've endured being a Tier 1, you're aware of the physical labour Amazon demands along with hitting rates and goals. You're aware of how your management team is rotated, so you can be criticized by a manager who isn't knowledgeable in your department. 

My warning is for new buildings. I've been with Amazon for nearly 5 years. I probably would've been there longer if I didn't transfer into a new building of its generation. Upper management hasn't figured out the kinks and gave me two departments to manage. It was an idealistic idea that wasn't ever practical. I was trained in an incomplete department for less than 2 months. Only 1 other person in the building was knowledgeable in the field, and he was unreliable. They put me in a harsh predicament knowing it wasn't fair, sensible, productive, and healthy for me. I was led by the blind and burnout because of it, while I made them money.

review_title: On a good day it's great, on a bad day it's torment.
pros: The compensation; it's why I have stayed as long as I have. My peers; there are some amazingly talented people working at Amazon. The hours; i manage my own time, it's about getting the work done. Career opportunities; there are 1000s of jobs available in Amazon, and if you are already an employee it is very easy to move around (too easy).
cons: The hiring and promotion processes; whichever candidate is first on an internal interview panel is likely the one to get offered the job, thanks to Amazons 2&5 hiring promise. The promise dictates that the candidate must get an update (post interview) in 2 days, and a decision in 5 days. that means that if you are 2nd on the panel, and are not due to be interviewed <5days from the first candidate, there's a high potential you lose out! (if all interviewers are inclined towards candidate #1). The hours; while the ability to work remotely is a Pro, the flexible hours are also a Con. If in a global role, your manager will expect you to be contactable pretty much all the time. This can get out of control if you as an employee don't set yourself boundaries, and push back. Time-zones don't mean anything to some. Pushing back could be interpreted as you not wanting to "raise the bar", and come promo time, that will be remembered. Competitive culture; it's about "me" and what I delivered, not about we. We all know it takes a team to deliver on anything, it's never just one person (unless you're a very talented one-man-band)!

job_title: Engineering Operations Technician in Columbus, OH
pros: The people I work with are cool. Day to day activities are relatively easy for the money. A lot of things are very lax. Mask mandates were very loosely enforced, and have been dropped. No peep from management about vaccination requirements. Great place to start a career, but I wouldn’t stay for longer than 5 years unless you fall in love with it.
cons: Managers spend 40-50 hours a week behind closed doors in meetings, most of the time resulting in decisions that are either completely disconnected from the workers, or just plain stupid. It’s all about metrics and red/green boxes being checked. Constantly making “two-way door” decisions, which really just means we flip flop constantly between opposite ends of the spectrum (the spectrum being between “dumb as hell” and “relatively effective”). AWS is cheap as all get out. Their buildings leak all over the place and equipment is not commissioned or tested properly before turning over to live services, resulting in making EOTs (we are the maintenance guys) lives hell. Promotions, raises, and pretty much anything else good is locked behind projects that are beyond the scope of your job. Nobody cares at all how good you are at your actual job, unless you do some major OT on your own time and do other people’s jobs for them.

job_title: Program Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
You get to meet some of the smartest and brightest coworkers and have a great peer support network. 

You get to be an owner of large scale projects that affect the Amazon network
cons:
No worklife balance. Leadership does not care if you work 12-15 hour days as long as you accomplish your tasks. If not, you'll feel the heat and pressure from leadership. They only care about them looking good and not your mental health. 

Very toxic work culture. No recognition for work with high expectations and no support. Common phrases here are: "You own your programs; I expect you to complete this task by this week (no support or direction on how to accomplish it); I think this is completely wrong, you figure out how to solve it." 

Leadership only cares about quantifiable metrics. In an organization full of ambiguity and different reports with different data (data integrity issues), you are pitted against the unknown and are expected to launch a project in a short period from to planning the mechanisms to full scale network adoption. 

I've lost all but one of my team members in less than a year. High turnover due to the stress of this organization. Your skills will be appreciated elsewhere.

job_title: Software Development Manager III in Seattle, WA
pros:
* Offsite/onsite work arrangements can be very flexible (depending on your specific team or organization)
* Can work on some of the most recognizable brands and products in the world, with some of the very best professionals in the world.
* The entire company lives and breathes its values (the Leadership Principles).
cons:
* Values (Leadership Principles) can be weaponized in some contexts and teams
* In some teams there are high levels of competitiveness and/or stress
* There are definitely "unregretted attrition targets" - if you're not at the midpoint of your role and level in your org for contributions (or better), you should be nervous. If you know you're at the bottom end for contributions and you've had some time in role and level, be very worried.

review_title: great flexible job, but the Position is BEING eliminated
pros:
Get to choose your hours, what ever times they drop as shifts.
Great pre-pandemic and early pandemic, after a year into the pandemic amazon decided to cut Hours, and reduced the cap, last october the CAP WAS reduced even further to an abysmal 12hrs.
wish personal shopper was there when i was still in school, wouldve been an entry in my resume, my schooling predates instore shopping.
-Hours used to be 20+ during pandemic times
cons:
-let me add there are more cons than pros, limited shifts are dropped and depending on the amount orders per day and you will be competing with other shoppers.
-they have been consistently lowering the hours cap throughout last year, to the point its POVERTY level income(you might as well not work at this point).
-they introduced that 10$ delivery fee and justified it with "need to cover operation costs" of whole foods shopping, but from what ive seen they wf themselves are not really benefiting from this.
-the same fee drastically reduced the amount orders wf stores get so theres less shifts and hours available for shoppers and the flex drivers.
-the fee is an attempt to reduce staffing to the point its more managable when WHOLE foods become the sole shopper in the stores.
-All wf stores with amazon shoppers in the us are being converted to wf only stores, so the whole job is being eliminated.
-current shoppers will have to eventually transfer to another amazon warehouse or facility if they have space or become wf shoppers, which is not in everyones best interest.
if your being hired for shopper position, run away its not worth it since some stores are converting in a few months.

review_title: Great pay but terrible work/life balance
job_title: Area Manager in Clear Brook, VA
pros: Great salary and initial sign on bonus, associates are great to work with, free lunch on Wednesday’s
cons: Beware, Work/life balance is terrible. A high salary doesn’t mean anything if you’re working 55 hours a week, and closer to 65-70 hour weeks from Black Friday through Christmas Day. Don’t expect to be off any holidays, Christmas Day is the only holiday they commit to giving you, expect to work a half day any other holiday during the year. The free lunch is nice, but if you don’t have time to eat it until 3 hours after it arrives isn’t nice. On your feet all day with short breaks if you’re lucky. Everyone is running around highly stressed all day, just unbelievable when managers request to leave during a shift due to mental health issues. It’s a revolving door of different managers, some get fired, a lot transfer out opening for a location with better morale and some just don’t return to work without giving a notice. I’ve never worked in as highly toxic environment as this place, senior leadership was absolutely terrible. Get ready to be owned by Amazon, they want to be priority 1, 2 and 3 in your life. If you’re married, don’t worry, it won’t be for long if you stay as a career. Lastly, EVERYONE is micromanaged from above including the site leader of the facility.

job_title: Risk Manager II in Seattle, WA
pros: health insurance, inclusive environments, salary
cons: up until 2015, the company culture felt like you had to give 110% of everything you got, and when you gave that 110%, they wanted more. After 2015, they made strides to change the dynamic and culture of the company where everyone was treated like a person again and not a number. Since 2020, they have started to reverse their ways and go back to pre 2015 culture.

pros:
Shifts are flexible: you start anywhere between 7 and 10 am.
Direct managers are understanding, very open to any concern.
Peers are in a similar age category, ~ between 25 and 35 y.o.
Working for Amazon in Romania sounds good for someone who doesn't know our company.
cons:
Salary is not really competitive on the local market. Amazon Romania cares more about saving money on wages instead of "raising the bar". Actually the "bar" has been undergoing a constant decrease since 2014 – raising it would be utopian when you have 2000+ employees.
After insisting with meal vouchers for several years, we got an increase this year and the maximum nationwide voucher value just increased as well.
Higher management also insists that higher wages are not a priority for the company and that, if we're not satisfied with the local targets (that are the highest worldwide), the job market is open.
+ 9-hour shifts.

job_title: Customer Success Manager (CSM) in Cape Town
pros: Good base salary, easy going dress code, undercover parking, free pick up drop off transport provided.
cons:
The bean bags, cry rooms, PlayStation, fridge full of juices...etc is all because you belong to them now. Associates/agents start and log off at fixed times after working their bot inspired roles.
Managers are expected to work until they have brake down or leave after they make your life miserable. The projects are endless, nothing ever gets completed, you are required to write narratives (and dare you do it in the wrong font!)
If you want help, you wont get it, you're told "It's in the Wiki" so go read a 10-50 page doc, but you also need to do 50 one-on-one meetings with the associates every month.
Meetings are created and dragged out by odd people they call Ops Managers. They have no personality and love the power trip this nerdy setup gives them.
Promotions are virtually non existent because you will be hired at a lower role than you applied for but you get paid what you want, so you think that there is a chance to progress - you are in fact told that you can be promoted within 6 months even! 
That is a complete lie and if you even look at someone (in management) in a tone they don't appreciate they will simply tell on you and you will end up on a Do NOT promote list for 6-12 months without your knowledge. It a very immature, gossip driven space that is career limiting in every aspect.
Associates will "cut a ticket" to complain about their disagreement with a colleague.

There are no perks aside from the FRUs (un-vested shares) which is the carrot while they keep beating you with the proverbial stick.
Low medical aid contribution insufficient for a single person, never mind a family of 3-4. 

There are many associates who smoke grass in the basement parking regularly - you can smell them when they come back to their desks. Many claim it helps them focus so they can reach their WIPH targets.

cons:
HORRIBLE pay for a class-A CDL holder position; I mean BOTTOM OF THE BARREL. You will NOT find worse pay for driving class-A. You are surveilled obsessively and constantly. There is a camera literally in your face in every vehicle and watching you all day, and while driving you are crucified for even the smallest things. You are expected to be perfect, and if you disagree with any part of Amazon's policies or decisions, you are wrong and they are right ALWAYS. Your opinion DOES NOT matter.

Despite the good things about the job, the risk and responsibility do not match the pay.

pros:
Speaking of the Cons:
Colleges are very friendly and will assist you if you have any problems with your duties.
cons: I'd like to share some important company information with you. First, the CTC that they told us about in our college during recruitment is completely different when it comes to the joining letter. Following that, you will be required to work Monday through Saturday from 11 a.m. to 10:30 p.m., as well as 1-2 Sundays. My first month's salary has yet to be paid. When I repeatedly asked about the financial issue, they said it would be adjusted in the next salary. Many employees are not paid for the first month. I was also surprised when I completed our KT Training in just one week, and then saw that they were recruiting members again the following week, with around 20 members and the process repeat again and again. There is a lot of job insecurity.

pros:
Speaking of the Cons:
Colleges are very friendly and will assist you if you have any problems with your duties.
cons: I'd like to share some important company information with you. First, the CTC that they told us about in our college during recruitment is completely different when it comes to the joining letter. Following that, you will be required to work Monday through Saturday from 11 a.m. to 10:30 p.m., as well as 1-2 Sundays. My first month's salary has yet to be paid. When I repeatedly asked about the financial issue, they said it would be adjusted in the next salary. Many employees are not paid for the first month. I was also surprised when I completed our KT Training in just one week, and then saw that they were recruiting members again the following week, with around 20 members and the process repeat again and again. There is a lot of job insecurity.

- Colleagues. Everyone is incredibly smart, driven, capable, and really fun to be around. I love my immediate team and the larger team I am a part of 
- Salary/benefits. The starting salary was significantly higher than at my previous job, and I received a signing bonus for the first two years, as well as Restricted Stock Units.
cons:
- Lots of bureaucracy and hoops to jump through. It's understandable because it's such a large organization, but there is a lot of it.

review_title: I've worked at Amazon numerous time holding a different position almost every time
pros: In stow you are normally left to do your job on your own AFTER training. You have others around you doing the same and other various jobs. You also have a radio you're able to use when you're not sure what to do about something. The "freedom" you are given in this position is one of my favorite aspects of working at Amazon. It's also why I'm having a hard time locating a job that is similar to the flow of Amazons. For those of you that have ADD/ADHD it is a blessing and a curse. For me personally if I was to sit at a desk all day, and do the same movements at the same pace in the same spot all day everyday. It would not take long for me to go into autopilot, eventually leading to me falling asleep or making a lot of mistakes. No matter what job you get at Amazon you will have to be able to self start and be trusted to go to your breaks and lunch at your specific time (give or take a few minutes) and most importantly COME BACK to your area TO SCAN ANYTHING if your job has anything to do with scanning anything. After your training and waiting weeks are up you will get a .5 - 1.0 point for being late back from a break or lunch. They do have a 3 min grace period. Benefits seem really good, I've never used the health insurance though. Seems good... You have the ability to cross train in other areas. I think for at least the warehouse I work in they are making people cross train as this facility is switching to a return warehouse. The point system has it good sides. They recently upgraded the amount of time it takes to earn more pto I believe you do not have to wait as long anymore. They also upgraded the ato.
cons: THEIR SYSTEM NEEDS SOME DARN WORK! So many issues have been created because of their systems, both on the job and personal life. You can opt in for emails to be sent any time you were given a point, late pass, applied pto, or got approval for ato. That's great. But it's the way you will always get these emails even if the system is wrong and tries to fix it. The AtoZ app shows your points, the day and time you were given a point, why you got it, and it'll tell you to dispute if needed. Be sure you always check your atoz app for this information. I HOPE A LOT OF PEOPLE READ THIS BECAUSE IM ABOUT TO SAVE YOUR BUTTS!!!! PTO is automatically approved. You can be at work and you feel like going home, all you have to do is put in the time you're leaving and what time your shift would've ended had you stayed. Then go clock out. Obviously you should inform your ambassador. Screenshot your confirmed time and hours or minutes from your atoz app. As soon as you click confirm and it shows whatever it shows screenshot it and keep it in a folder on your phone. ATO has to be put in and approved by whoever. Same goes for this. When it is or if its approved, screenshot it. Bc this is an area you can get mix ups in the system. If you're going to be late or take a day off and you want to use your PTO make sure you screenshot your confirmation. I have had it MANY MANY MANY times where I put it in and I'll clock in late, only to see later that they gave me points for it. Sometimes they will STILL take your PTO time !!!! Sometimes they might catch it on their own. But more often than not they wont. Screenshot your point and your PTO and add the screenshot of whatever you used to cover it to start with. Start a case with HR from the app. Check back daily. IF YOU ARE CLOSE TO YOUR LIMIT ON POINTS do not wait. Put in the hr case and then go to the hr desk at lunch or beginning of shift because they could start the process of firing you no matter what it says. But I have had it to where my screenshots didnt matter because their system said it looked fine. When covid started they decided out of the blue on our first day to change the shift by 15 min difference for the start and end . They didnt change everyones in the system so I was getting 2-3 email a day saying I was late, took a early lunch or was back late from it, and that I left early from work. I didnt even notice until I got an email saying I was out of late passes, and ATO, that my points were at 6 already. I was able to fix it but my husband to this very day believes I was getting to work late every night and leaving work early every morning to cheat . So I kindly say to Amazon - FIX YOUR MFN AUTOMATIC SYSTEM CRAP

review_title: Most of what you have heard might be true
pros:
Peculiar culture about writing - it could be really powerful and succinct way of communication and knowledge sharing.
People care about feedback, and design many ways to collect them. 
Culture of being direct could mean efficiency (sometimes) as people are used to provide direct feedback / challenge certain ideas / ask questions.
Given the size of the company, many opportunities within if you do not want to leave
cons:
Depending on personality, some people find it difficult to fit into the direct culture, where some can be overly direct or even aggressive at others.
Depending on the team, you may no longer feel like working at a start-up but rather a large, mature org with many processes to follow. 
Employees are forced to use certain internal tools than those broadly available ones on the market, and those tools are not the best in class...

pros:
1. There is no interview for entry level associates, so it does make getting the job easier. After you accept their job offer you schedule your drug testing and then you get your orientation date.
2. Job tasks are very simple, repetitive, and easy to learn.
3. Management are very nice, team oriented, understanding, and easy to talk to.
cons:
1. For me is the pay, the pay is very low in my opinion, we could be compensated better for the work we do. 
2. Staff can come off as very un-motivated and very pessimistic at times. They often complain about the working conditions, other people, the workload, etc.
3. No interviews: It is nice to have an easy opportunity to work for Amazon, but also there is no regard for vetting people who don't qualify to work there (some people can't lift heavy enough weight or have various medical conditions that would prohibit their ability to work there.)
4. The company has offered false bonuses to their employees (Last year new hires were promised a bonus if they continued to stay past peak season, none of them received any bonus at all despite staying with Amazon past peak season. )

job_title: Fulfillment Associate in San Bernardino, CA
pros: You're paid a reasonable amount, and to my knowledge they seem to give raises pretty frequently to people who continue working there. Also, they offer higher hourly wages for shifts that need additional workers (i.e. $22/hr instead of $17/hr), or night shifts. The management wasn't too overbearing, which was a huge plus. The company has expectations/quotas that they want you to meet, but they also openly admit that unless you're clocking in the bottom 3% for scanning (and you would have to be going REALLY slow to hit that) then you're not really in danger of any disciplinary action. There's shifts available 24/7 and you can pick up extra shifts as much or as little as you want, so there's definitely room to make overtime if that's something you want. Overall not a terrible job if you're looking for work fast, I would've kept working there but had to resign to focus on school.
cons: The work can be a little active/strenuous (nothing too horrible though), but considering the fact that you're literally working in a warehouse that's to be expected. Be prepared to be on your feet almost the entire shift, but again: don't apply for a warehouse job if you're not prepared to be moderately active when on the clock. Your breaks include the time it takes to walk to the break room, which can be a little far away depending on where you're working in the warehouse.

review_title: Solid place to start a career, but easy to burn out. Don't stay too long.
job_title: Software Development Engineer I in Santa Monica, CA
pros:
• Solid place to learn best practices of quality software engineering. Lots of established processes and documentation ensure only good quality code is shipped out. The environment is very structured. 
• Firsthand access to learning and mastering all aspects of AWS, as Amazon uses its own product to host its own infrastructure. Any training you can find here is extremely valuable, and carry from job to job.
cons:
• Company is "frugal", but in practice, extremely stingy. Snacks aren't free, they're placed behind a vending machine you need to pay for. The only napkins you get are paper towel rolls. Pro from this is that I can bet that with WFH becoming more popular, Amazon is probably going to use this to cut costs on their office buildings for software developers. 
• At least for my team, there was a high turnover. There were 14 people on the team when I joined, but 10 when I left. Those 10 were not the same 14, and someone was leaving every month. We had portraits of people organized in order of likeliness to leave and called that the "graveyard". I thought it was a joke... until it wasn't. But that's just my experience.
• Upward mobility is easy at first, then it becomes exponentially harder without too much payoff. People usually just promote and leave for another big company that pays more and has better perks since it's not worth the overwork to get to that next level. You're going to see more people earlier in their career, and the "veteran" Amazonian is incredibly rare. 
• There are incentives and clear goals to make it to the next level, but chances are, the workload is so high that you're probably going to burn out before you get there, and transfer out before you vest all your RSUs. WLB is not really valued, just work.
